title: In a philosophical theory, what are internal and external inconsistencies? - Quora

response.answer_text: Internal consistency refers to the argument presented. Does its conclusions logically follow from its premises? Can one generate any contradictions from the argument itself? This is usually measured in terms of validity. External consistency might refer to whether the theory is consistence with all the relevant facts. Is there some fact about the world which might be inconsistent, or incompatible with a premise of the argument? If any premises are propositions about facts, are they correct or not? This is usually measured in terms of soundness. Because a sound argument must also be valid, a critique of a theory will usually begin with an analysis of its validity. If the argument presented for the theory is not valid, then that’s sufficient to reject or modify the argument or theory. Only when the argument is found to be valid will we find the need to proceed to fact checking.

It’s fairly simple: Internal inconsistency is when something does not meet the basic criteria for inclusion in a philosophical category. For example, if something is determined to be ‘not logical’ or ‘not ethical’. Logical consistency might be about completeness or reasonableness, for example, whereas ethics might be internally inconsistent when it fails external criteria. External inconsistency is generally failure in the real world. For example, the theory that all swans are white was famously disproved by discovering black swans in Australia. If it happens that we live in a simulation, a theory that rejects the role of technology might be externally inconsistent. ‘Internal’ generally concerns knowledge and epistemology, whereas ‘external’ concerns realism, practicality, and testing.
